body:
Currently every plugin is `git clone`d into '~/.local/share/nvim/site/pack/core/opt' and managed assuming it is a local copy of some remote repository. This allows the following useful assumptions:
- All plugins managed by `vim.pack` are located only in one specific directory.
- All plugins in one specific directory are managed only by `vim.pack`.

There were suggestions to add support for so called "local plugins" (as "unmanaged plugins" in 'vim-plug'). The idea is to allow to load plugins from any local path but not manage them at all. I.e. something like this:
- `vim.pack.add('~/my-plugins/plugin1')` adds the path to 'runtimepath' and executes 'plugin/' / 'after/plugin/' files.
- `vim.pack.update()` and `vim.pack.del()` don't know/care about such plugins.

My personal preference is that suggesting to manually add such plugins is okay. For example, by putting such plugins in '~/.local/share/nvim/site/pack/mine/start' or '.../mine/opt' and manually call `:packadd`.

comment_data.body:
> The idea is to allow to load plugins from any local path but not manage them at all. I.e. something like this:

git already supports `file:///` URIs. What's missing from that? The fact that `vim.pack` does a "clone" from the `file:///` URI seems completely fine, AFAICT. Why is it worth extra logic and surface area to support a different flavor?

> * `vim.pack.add('~/my-plugins/plugin1')` adds the path to 'runtimepath' and executes 'plugin/' / 'after/plugin/' files.

`vim.pack.add('file:///home/foo/my-plugins/plugin1')` already works.

> * `vim.pack.update()` and `vim.pack.del()` don't know/care about such plugins.

update/del already work with `file:///`.

It might require the user to `git init` in the local dir. That's a totally fine constraint.

I personally agree that special-casing local plugins feels a bit too much. The reasons for doing so seems to be to enable easier local plugin development:
- Not having to `git init` in plugin's directory.
- If it is a Git repo, not having to commit new changes and `vim.pack.update({ 'plugin1' }, { force = true })` each time.

Both of these cases are resolved by putting plugins in the '\~/.local/share/nvim/site/pack/mine/{start,opt}/plugin1' or '\~/.config/nvim/pack/mine/{start,opt}/plugin1'.

The idea was brought up by @lewis6991 and @clason, so maybe they can give more details.

When developing/contributing to plugins, I often (have to) switch between upstream and my local checkout for testing WIP changes on the feature branch, or quick A/B testing between the branch and `main`. Being able to simply point the plugin manager to the checkout temporarily reduces _a lot_ of friction for this.

As someone who maintains and contributes to lots of plugins, reducing friction here is high value to me. It's also a common feature in many (all?) third party managers and isn't complex to support.

My current manager simply detects if source is a local path, and if it is it just symlinks the dir into `opt` instead of `git clone`, then update operations work as normal.

If I can't have this supported then I simply won't use `vim.pack`, and thus won't contribute to it going forward.
git clone file:// only clones committed content—any local changes that haven't been committed won't be included in the clone. I ran into this today while migrating vim.pack...

Yes, the behavior is expected, but indeed a valid argument.

The current suggestion for "local plugins" is to put them in a separate 'pack/mine/{start,opt}' directory.

As there are tests already, I'll explore the symlink approach. But as far as my research has shown, creating symlinks on Windows requires admin rights. If true, this is not ideal, but might be not crucial.

It seems like a junction link might be able to work on windows. I did have one issue with it though when trying it briefly locally now. I tried to create it through `vim.uv.fs_symlink(path, new_path, { junction = true })`, but I couldn't get it to work with that. I also briefly remember packer.nvim used opt/start, and judging from this commit: https://github.com/wbthomason/packer.nvim/commit/851c62c5ecd3b5adc91665feda8f977e104162a5 I would assume they maybe had it working

It did however seem to work if I created the link manually in `cmd` with something like this: `mklink /J "<path>" "<new_path>"`

> Being able to simply point the plugin manager to the checkout temporarily reduces _a lot_ of friction for this.

What's the hold up with repointing your git HEAD between local vs upstream branches instead of having 2 working trees?

Have we figured out what we want from `vim.pack` with this? I was debating giving it a shot to implement a PR for this, but am unsure about what we would want for some of the actions

- `vim.pack.add('~/my-plugins/plugin1')` symlinks it to 
   `vim.fs.joinpath(vim.fn.stdpath("data"), "site", "pack", "core", "opt", "plugin1")`
- `vim.pack.del({ "plugin1" })` removes the symlink
- `vim.pack.update` ??
- `vim.pack.get()` resolves the original path, and tries to resolve version using git (?)

> I was debating giving it a shot to implement a PR for this, but am unsure about what we would want for some of the actions

Thanks for the enthusiasm, but it will probably lead to fewer complications if this waits until there is a lockfie support (#34776, it is in the works and PR should be up *soon*-ish). Mostly because both local plugin and lockfile support will touch a lot of the same areas.

But to answer the question, the plan is indeed something like you outlined, plus:
- State of the plugin never changes. Be it in `vim.pack.update()` or during "install" / "checkout".
- Confirmation buffer should show a dedicated information about it (that it is local).
- `vim.pack.get()` should provide specification as for regular plugin, but also will probably introduce a new dedicated `type` field that will be (currently) one of `'git'` or `'local'`.

I have a plan to at least try to resolve this with suggestion PR before 0.12.

> It seems like a junction link might be able to work on windows. I did have one issue with it though when trying it briefly locally now. I tried to create it through `vim.uv.fs_symlink(path, new_path, { junction = true })`, but I couldn't get it to work with that. I also briefly remember packer.nvim used opt/start, and judging from this commit: [wbthomason/packer.nvim@851c62c](https://github.com/wbthomason/packer.nvim/commit/851c62c5ecd3b5adc91665feda8f977e104162a5) I would assume they maybe had it working
> 
> It did however seem to work if I created the link manually in `cmd` with something like this: `mklink /J "<path>" "<new_path>"`

The junction does work on windows however you have to use absolute paths when calling `vim.uv.fs_symlink`.

```lua
:pwd
-- C:/Users/user

-- Works
=vim.uv.fs_symlink('C:/Users/user/original_file.txt', 'C:/Users/user/junction_file.txt', { junction = true })

-- Fails
=vim.uv.fs_symlink('./original_file.txt', 'C:/Users/user/junction_file.txt', { junction = true })
=vim.uv.fs_symlink('C:/Users/user/original_file.txt', './junction_file.txt', { junction = true })
```

All you need to do is to resolve the absolute path first.

```lua
-- Sample
local source = vim.fn.fnamemodify('./original_file.txt', ':p')
local target = vim.fn.fnamemodify('./juntion_file.txt', ':p')
vim.uv.fs_symlink(source, target, { junction = true })
```

I found that some months ago and I used `fnamemodify` as a workaround.

```
vim.pack.add { "file:///Users/user/path/plugin.name" }
```

works... except: the info returned using `vim.pack.get()` does not return a "src =" as part of the spec. This causes `vim.pack.update()` without specifying any plugins to fail because of the nil src entry.

To add to the confusion `vim.pack.get({ "plugin.name" }) does return the appropriate source.

Arrgggghhhhh!

Error is mine.  Mostly. I'd earlier typoed the plugin name, using `plugin-nvim` instead of `plugin.nvim`.  I corrected the typo once I figured out what I'd done wrong.  However, nvim left the bad plugin named folder in `/Users/marc/.local/share/nvim/site/pack/core/opt`.  It was the bad, i.e. non-existent plugin that was causing the error.

So, my error.  But maybe neovim could catch something like this with a better error than failing to update?

> So, my error. But maybe neovim could catch something like this with a better error than failing to update?

For such things there is a `:checkhealth` planned (#34777). Would you mind adding a brief description of your use case to that issue, please?
Done.  Also: I could not delete the bogus entry using vim.pack.del() -- I had to blow away the bad folder using the shell and remove the bogus entry from nvim-pack-lock.json by hand.

> Also: I could not delete the bogus entry using vim.pack.del() -- I had to blow away the bad folder using the shell and remove the bogus entry from nvim-pack-lock.json by hand.

Now *that* looks like not intended. I quickly tested and it seems that this has nothing to do with `file://`. Error during installation will wrongly add to the lockfile. Can you please also create an issue (sorry for troubles) with repro steps?

title: Local plugin support in `vim.pack`

type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality
type.name: Enhancement
